metadata.sermon_start_end: Whenever there’s a war, the universal human tendency to divide up the world into “we” and “they” becomes even more pronounced than usual. “Our” side is good; “their” side is evil. We measure everything by ourselves, by our own assessment of what is good and right. [...] Open to me the gates of righteousness, that I may enter through them and give thanks to the Lord.… This is the Lord’s doing; it is marvelous in our eyes. AMEN.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon fails Dekker's requirement of focusing on one specific pericope. It jumps between Psalm 118, Ezekiel 12, 16, 18, 21, and Romans. It treats the Bible as a source for a 'coherent, holistic biblical theology' rather than letting one text say what can be found nowhere else.
quotes: When I was asked to choose a text... I chose Psalm 118.
In the passage from Ezekiel that was read tonight...
Think of what Paul says in the great eighth chapter of Romans...
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Select either Psalm 118 or a specific chapter of Ezekiel. Stop using other texts to 'explain away' the specific, perhaps uncomfortable, voice of the primary text.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: There is an awareness of the original context (Gentiles vs Israel), but it is quickly instrumentalized for a contemporary political critique. The preacher uses the text to support a pre-existing theological framework (Calvinism/Prevenient grace) rather than excavating the specific historical-linguistic depth of the passage.
quotes: “Nations” in the Old Testament usually refers to the Gentiles. It refers to everyone except Israel, the elect people.
Ezekiel, who admittedly loves lurid imagery, compares God’s people to a newborn abandoned by the roadside...
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Engage with the specific Hebrew concepts of 'tsedaqah' in the context of Psalm 118's liturgy of entry, rather than importing Pauline definitions of righteousness immediately.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is sharp and concrete, specifically regarding the American political zeitgeist of 2005, war, and the 'self-help' culture. It avoids vague 'be good' pieties by attacking the nationalistic 'we are the righteous' myth.
quotes: We are sure that God is on the side of America. After all, we Americans — as the president constantly reminds us — are good people.
I have made a study of what goes on in video games... And what about the movies?
It’s a billion-dollar business; just take a look at the self-help shelf in any bookstore.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Ensure the application flows from the *specific* text rather than using the text as a hook for a general (though sharp) cultural critique.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon moves back and forth between the biblical world and the contemporary world reasonably well. It does not follow a strict 'first exegesis then application' structure, which Dekker appreciates.
quotes: This suggests America today. We have been taught to think of ourselves as the elect...
The picture here is one of a rebellious house... This refers to Israel itself... As we deserve.
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Deepen the 're-creation' of the Word so the hearer feels 'expounded' by the text itself rather than by the preacher's political observations.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: Strong adherence to this thesis. The sermon emphasizes 'misery' (rebellious house, heart of stone) and 'redemption' (God's performative word, alien righteousness) as the work of God alone. It correctly identifies gratitude as the response to God's deed.
quotes: I am a rebellious house all wrapped up in one person...
It is taking you and me and, yes, “chastening us sorely,” but in doing so he is “opening the gates of righteousness to us”
The Lord has spoken the word and performed it; “he has reckoned us righteous.”
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Maintain the focus on the 'misery' of the specific text's audience before jumping to the universal human condition.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: While the sermon mentions judgment and being 'lost in time' (perishing society), it leans heavily on a monergistic grace that softens the 'narrow way' of human responsibility. The 'two ways' as a choice for the hearer are secondary to God's overriding agency.
quotes: God’s purpose is something different from the purpose of either party.
He will win this struggle that goes on within us, because he is God and we aren’t.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Address the hearer more directly as a 'willing and responsible being' who must choose the narrow way, rather than only a passive recipient of a 'cleansing operation'.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is clearly the telos. The sermon moves from the problem of human righteousness to the 'alien' righteousness of Christ. It upholds the doctrine of grace as the 'deepest of our life'.
quotes: Being reckoned righteous by Jesus Christ means being assimilated into his righteousness.
I don’t want my righteousness — I want his righteousness.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Connect Christ more organically to the specific Old Testament imagery of the 'Gate' or the 'Cornerstone' in Psalm 118, rather than switching to a Pauline/Lutheran vocabulary.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 22 minutes, the sermon meets the minimum requirement for 'breadth' to achieve 'depth'. It takes time to wrestle with the text and the zeitgeist.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Use the time to go deeper into one text rather than covering multiple chapters of Ezekiel.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short of Dekker’s primary formal requirement: it is not an exposition of *one specific* Bible passage, but a thematic synthesis of several. However, it strongly aligns with Dekker’s substantive requirements regarding the 'three parts' and the rejection of general, 'nice' truths in favor of a concrete, psychological, and political critique of the human condition.
strengths: Concrete application: The critique of nationalistic righteousness and the 'self-help' industry is sharp and contemporary.
Theological consistency: Strong emphasis on the 'misery' of man and the 'redemption' as an act of God (prevenient grace).
Duration: Sufficient length to allow for theological movement.
weaknesses: Lack of scriptural specificity: By jumping between texts, the preacher avoids the 'nowhere else' quality of a single pericope.
Theological imposition: The sermon at times feels like a lecture on 'Calvinist inclinations' rather than a text-driven proclamation.
Weak 'Two Ways': The emphasis on God's performative word risks making human responsibility and the 'narrow way' appear irrelevant.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is a strong theological speech that functions as a sermon in its application and substantive depth, but it fails the formal test of being an 'exposition of a specific Bible passage.' It is more a 'speech about the Gospel' using various texts as illustrations.
